title: The Holiday That Brought Everyone Together
description: A story about the holiday that brought everyone together.
content:
Adaeze loved holidays because the house changed on those mornings—quieter in some ways, warmer in others. People woke up without rushing. The smell of cooking came earlier than usual. Her mother dressed carefully, and her father smiled more.

She'd never really stopped to wonder why certain days were like this.

One morning she asked her mother why they were preparing special food. Her mother sat down beside her and explained—this was a religious holiday, a day that reminded people to be grateful, to forgive, to look outward toward others rather than inward toward themselves. Adaeze listened carefully. She hadn't known holidays carried messages. She'd thought they were just days off.

Relatives arrived through the morning—some she saw often, some she hadn't seen in a long time. The house filled with greetings and noise and the particular warmth of people who were glad to see each other. An elder sat down with the children before the meal and spoke slowly and clearly about what the day meant: gratitude, forgiveness, the responsibility of people to one another.

Adaeze listened closely. The words were simple but they sat with her.

After the meal, she helped distribute food to neighbors. She carried plates down the street with her cousin and watched people's faces when they answered their doors—surprise first, then something else. Something warmer. She felt the warmth herself, carrying it back home.

That evening, sitting with her cousins and talking about nothing in particular, she noticed how easy it was. No schedule, no rush, nowhere to be. The holiday had made space for this.

She noticed too that people were kinder during the day. Arguments that might have happened didn't. Patience stretched further than usual. She wondered why that was—whether the day reminded people of what they valued, or whether it simply slowed everyone down enough to behave like they meant to.

When she went to school and talked with friends about their own holidays—different occasions, different traditions—she found that the shape underneath them was usually similar. Gathering. Gratitude. Remembering something that mattered. Giving something away.

She decided to pay more attention to holidays from now on. Not just as free days, but as days with something to say.

title: The Festival of Our Traditions
description: A story about the festival of our traditions.
content:
Dayo woke up early because the village was already moving.

Drums in the distance. Elders walking with purpose. The smell of food being prepared since before sunrise. He dressed in his traditional clothes—his grandmother smoothing the fabric on his shoulders with both hands—and went outside.

The village square was filling. Songs rose in the local language, rhythms he'd heard all his life without fully knowing what they meant. Dancers moved in patterns that told stories without words. Dayo watched and tried to understand what he was seeing.

An elder gathered the children and spoke to them in the shade of a large tree. He talked about how their ancestors had lived—how they'd worked, settled disputes, raised children, survived difficulties. The cultural holiday, he explained, was how those lessons stayed alive. Without it, things that had taken generations to learn could disappear in a single one.

Dayo thought about that. Things disappearing in a single generation. It seemed fast and also possible.

Food was shared among everyone—families, neighbors, visitors who'd come from other villages. No one was left out. Dayo noticed that the sharing wasn't formal or organized; it just happened, the way things happen in places where the habit is deep.

In the afternoon, older youths taught the younger children traditional dance steps. Dayo got the footwork wrong three times and then right, and the older boy teaching him laughed and said that was exactly how he'd learned too. Culture moved from one person to another that way—imperfectly, patiently, through practice.

Stories were told around a fire as the sun went down. Some were funny. Some were serious. Some were both. Each one had a point, but the point arrived at the end, after you'd already been pulled into the story. That was how it worked.

Dayo went home tired and full of things to think about.

He understood now that the holiday wasn't just celebration. It was memory made into action—a way of keeping the past present, of making sure what mattered to one generation could matter to the next.

He wanted to remember it properly.

title: The Day the Nation Rested
description: A story about the day the nation rested.
content:
When Seun woke up, there was no rush for school. His parents told him it was a public holiday.

The streets were quieter than usual. The market wasn't running. There was a stillness to the morning that he didn't often feel.

He asked his father what the day was about.

His father poured tea for both of them and sat down. Public holidays, he explained, were days set aside to remember something important in the country's history. Independence. Sacrifice. People who had worked or fought or built something that everyone now benefited from without always realizing it.

"It's a way of not forgetting," his father said.

Seun watched a ceremony on television later—leaders speaking, flags raised carefully, a crowd standing in respectful quiet. He noticed how people held themselves differently during it. Straighter. More attentive.

In the afternoon his neighbors organized a cleanup of the street. Seun joined in. People came out of their houses with brooms and bags, working alongside each other without much conversation, just the shared task. An older neighbor told stories while they swept—about what the neighborhood had looked like decades ago, who had lived there, what had changed.

History told from the street up felt different from history in a textbook. More real, somehow. More connected to the ground he was standing on.

He thought about the word his father had used. Not forgetting. He hadn't thought about remembering as a responsibility before. He'd thought of it as something that either happened or didn't—you either remembered things or you didn't.

But public holidays were a choice to remember. A decision made every year to stop and say: this mattered. These people mattered. This moment in our story mattered.

At dinner he shared this thought with his family and they talked about it for a while. His mother added things he hadn't considered. His younger sister asked questions that were harder to answer than they looked.

He went to bed thinking the holiday had given him more than a day off. It had given him something to carry forward.

title: The Sharing Garden
description: A story about the sharing garden.
content:
Emma's garden was the best one on Maple Street, and she knew it. Bright red tomatoes. Sunflowers as tall as her dad. Roses in four different colors. She'd planted every seed herself and tended it every afternoon without being asked.

Across the street, Mr. Chen would wave from his porch. "Beautiful garden, Emma."

"Thank you," she'd say, and go back to her weeding.

She liked it that way. Her garden. Her work. Her space.

Mr. Chen had a garden too, but it wasn't doing well. His flowers drooped even when he watered them. His tomato plants were thin and pale.

Emma noticed. She didn't say anything.

Then one windy afternoon, Mr. Chen's main tomato plant toppled over. The stake had snapped at the base. Emma watched from her yard as he tried to hammer in a new one. His hands shook—he was very old—and after ten minutes he gave up and went inside, moving slowly.

Emma felt something uncomfortable sit in her chest. She didn't know what to call it.

That evening she sat on her porch and looked at her garden. Everything was in its place.

She thought about Mr. Chen. He waved every morning, even when she forgot to wave back. Last year he'd helped her dad change a flat tire in the rain. Every Christmas he left cookies for the mail carrier.

She thought about his tomato plant lying in the dirt.

Maybe I should help.

But then she thought about all her own work—the weeding still left to do, the beans that needed picking.

She went inside. The uncomfortable feeling came with her.

She was quiet all through dinner. Her mom noticed.

"What's going on?"

Emma explained about Mr. Chen's plant. About how she hadn't done anything.

Her dad put down his fork. "You know, the best gardens aren't really about the plants."

"What are they about?"

"Who you share them with."

Emma thought about that for a long time after dinner. She wasn't sure it made sense. But she wasn't sure it didn't, either.

The next afternoon she crossed the street and knocked on Mr. Chen's door.

He answered looking surprised. "Emma! What can I do for you?"

"Actually—" She held up her bag of stakes and gardening twine. "I was hoping to help with your tomato plant. If that's okay."

His whole face changed. "That would be wonderful. I'm not as strong as I used to be. Come, come."

They worked side by side. Emma tied the plant properly, showing him the knot her grandfather had taught her. Mr. Chen showed her an old trick with garlic water that kept aphids away—something his grandmother had used.

Emma hadn't expected it to be fun. It was.

She kept coming back. Every day after school, one hour in Mr. Chen's garden before her own.

He couldn't do the heavy digging anymore, but he knew things Emma didn't. Which plants to put next to each other. When to water and when to let the soil dry. How to read the color of a leaf.

His garden started changing. The flowers stood up straight. The tomatoes grew fat and red.

And something else grew too, slower and harder to see. Mr. Chen told her about gardens he'd planted in four different countries when he was young. Emma told him about school, about her friends, about the things she wanted to be someday. He listened like what she said mattered.

By the end of summer, both gardens were full.

One evening Mr. Chen handed her a basket—tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers, more than her family could eat in a week.

"For you," he said.

Emma looked at the vegetables and felt something she hadn't expected. Not just happy. Full, somehow. Like the feeling was too big for just one person.

"Mr. Chen," she said, "I think these taste better because we grew them together."

He smiled. "I was just thinking the same thing."

Emma had an idea. She talked to Mr. Chen about it, and then they talked to the neighbors—all of them, up and down Maple Street.

On the last Saturday of summer, everyone came out. They brought vegetables and flowers and dishes they'd made. The whole street smelled like food and cut grass and something harder to name.

Kids ran between the tables. The older neighbors sat in lawn chairs and talked. Mrs. Wilson from next door swapped tomato seeds with the family at the end of the block, people who'd lived thirty feet apart for years without ever really talking.

Emma's mom found her sitting with Mr. Chen near the end of the afternoon.

"You did something good here," her mom said.

"I just helped with a garden."

Mr. Chen shook his head. "You did more than that. You showed up. That's rarer than people think."

Emma looked at the neighbors around her—most of them strangers to each other a few months ago, now swapping seeds and stories and plates of food—and understood, for the first time, what her dad had meant.

The garden was beautiful. It had always been beautiful. But this was better.

title: The Honest Mistake
description: A story about the honest mistake.
content:
Jordan was walking home from soccer practice, cleats over his shoulder, thinking about the shot he'd almost scored, when he saw the wallet.

Brown leather. Lying near the bus stop like someone had just set it down and forgotten to pick it up.

He looked around. The street was empty.

He picked it up and opened it. Credit cards. A few photos. And five twenty-dollar bills, crisp and flat.

A hundred dollars.

Jordan stood very still.

He'd been saving for a video game for three months. He had thirty dollars. The game cost sixty. His friends played it online every weekend and he always had to sit out.

Finders keepers, said a voice in his head. Nobody saw. You need this more than whoever dropped it.

But there was another voice too, quieter: Someone lost this. Right now, somewhere, they're looking for it.

Jordan sat down on the nearby bench and opened the wallet again, more carefully this time.

The ID card showed a woman named Patricia Williams. Oak Street. Three blocks away.

In the photo section, she was smiling with two little kids at what looked like a birthday party. Someone had drawn a star on the corner of the photo in marker—one of the kids, probably.

Jordan thought about how he'd felt last year when he'd lost the baseball card his grandpa had given him. The signed one. He'd cried for a week, and that was just a card.

He already knew what he was going to do.

His hand shook a little when he rang the doorbell on Oak Street.

A woman answered. Her eyes were red. She'd clearly been crying.

"Yes?" Her voice was tired.

"I found this," Jordan said, holding out the wallet. "I think it's yours."

Her hand went to her mouth. She took it, looked inside, and started crying again—different tears this time.

"Everything's here," she said. "All of it."

"You dropped it near the bus stop on Maple. I think it happened when you were getting off with grocery bags."

She told him the money was for her kids' school lunches and supplies for the month. She'd filed a police report. She'd been searching for two hours.

Jordan felt something warm move through his chest. Not the warmth of being thanked—something quieter than that. The feeling of having done the right thing and knowing it.

She reached for the money. "Please, let me give you something—"

"No, thank you," Jordan said. "I didn't bring it back for a reward."

She looked at him for a moment. "Then why?"

Jordan thought about it. "Because it was yours. And because I'd want someone to do the same."

Walking home, Jordan felt different.

He still didn't have the sixty dollars. He'd have to keep saving. His friends would keep playing without him for another month.

But something inside him felt good in a way he couldn't quite explain. Better than winning a game. Better than buying something new.

That night at dinner, he told his family. His little sister Maria stared at him like he'd grown a second head.

"You gave back a hundred dollars?"

"It wasn't mine to keep."

His dad reached over and squeezed his shoulder and didn't say anything, which somehow said more than words would have.

Two days later, his mom called him downstairs. Ms. Williams was in the living room with her two kids and a wrapped package.

"I know you said no reward," she said. "But we made you something."

Inside was a small handmade coupon book. Free math tutoring—she was a math teacher. A home-cooked dinner. A coupon that just said For a rainy day.

"We wanted to give you something real," she explained. "You did something real for us."

Jordan looked at the coupon book and felt his eyes sting a little.

He put it on his shelf that night, next to his soccer trophies.

He thought about the two voices he'd heard at the bus stop—the one that said keep it and the one that said give it back. They'd felt equally loud in the moment. He'd almost listened to the wrong one.

The following week he saved enough for the game and bought it. It was fun. He and his friends played online every weekend.

But the warm feeling from returning the wallet? That was still there too, underneath everything, steady in a way that the game wasn't.

He told his friend about it once. "I don't know if I would have given it back," his friend said.

"I almost didn't," Jordan said honestly. "But I'm really glad I did."

title: Words That Hurt
description: A story about words that hurt.
content:
Lily loved art. She drew gardens and animals and flowers with soft watercolors, and Ms. Garcia always pinned her work near the front of the room.

When Maya joined their class in October, Ms. Garcia asked Lily to help her get settled. Lily showed her the supply shelves, the cubbies, the way the classroom worked.

During free draw, Lily made her usual style—a garden with butterflies, birds moving between flowers. Maya worked quietly beside her and drew something completely different. Robots. Buildings. Tight, precise lines with rulers and sharp pencils.

Lily leaned toward her friend Emma. "That's weird," she whispered.

It wasn't quite quiet enough. Maya's shoulders pulled in. She moved her paper closer to herself without looking up.

Over the next week, Lily kept going.

"Why do you always draw robots? That's not really art."

"Your colors are so dark. Don't you know how to use bright ones?"

Some of the other kids started laughing at Maya's drawings. Following Lily's lead.

Maya stopped raising her hand in class. She stopped sharing her work. She moved to the corner table and turned her notebook so no one could see it.

Lily noticed. She told herself Maya was just being sensitive. She didn't look too hard at what she'd done.

The following week, Lily brought in a new drawing—a sunset over the ocean that she'd worked on for three evenings. She was proud of it.

During sharing time, Emma said, "It's okay. You always draw the same stuff though."

Another kid: "Sunsets are kind of basic."

Someone laughed. "My little cousin draws things like that."

Lily's chest tightened. Her face went hot. She made it to the bathroom before the tears came.

She sat on the floor of the stall and cried. Her drawing wasn't boring. She'd tried so hard. How could they say that?

She looked at herself in the mirror afterward—puffy eyes, red face.

And then it hit her. Not slowly. All at once, like a door opening.

This is exactly how Maya feels.

Every time Lily had said something about her drawings. Every "weird" and "dark" and "not really art." Maya had felt this. Maybe worse, because it hadn't been just one moment.

Lily's stomach turned. She thought about Maya moving to the corner table, hiding her notebook, going quiet in the ways she used to be bright.

I did that.

Finding Maya at recess wasn't hard. She was alone at the edge of the blacktop, notebook closed on her lap.

"Hi. Can I talk to you?"

Maya looked at her the way you look at someone you've learned not to trust. "I guess."

Lily sat down. Her heart was pounding. "I'm sorry. I said mean things about your art. A lot of times. That wasn't okay."

Maya was quiet for a moment. "You really hurt my feelings. I love drawing the way I draw. It's what makes me happy."

"I know. And that should have been enough. I was wrong." Lily hesitated. "I think I said those things because your art was so different from mine, and it made me uncomfortable. But that was my problem."

"It was," Maya said. Not mean. Just honest.

"Can I see your notebook?" Lily asked. "For real this time."

Maya hesitated. Then slowly opened it.

The pages were full of things Lily hadn't imagined. Detailed robot designs with tiny labeled parts. Futuristic buildings that looked like they could actually stand. Spaceships with working logic to them.

"Maya," Lily said. "These are incredible. How do you plan all the details?"

Maya looked at her, checking if it was real. "You actually think so?"

"I really do. I could never draw like this. Every line is so precise."

"And I could never draw like you," Maya said, quietly. "The way your animals look like they're about to move."

They sat there for a moment, both looking at each other's work.

In art class the next day, Lily raised her hand. "Ms. Garcia? Could Maya show everyone her robot designs? They're really amazing."

Maya's head came up, surprised.

She showed the class. She explained how each robot was built, what it could do, how she planned the joints. The room went quiet in the way rooms go quiet when something genuinely interesting is happening.

"Can you teach me that?" a boy asked.

"I want to try robots," someone else said.

At recess, kids gathered around Maya's notebook. She was talking, explaining, showing—the exact opposite of the corner table.

Ms. Garcia pulled Lily aside after class. "That took character," she said. "I noticed you weren't kind to Maya at first."

"I know," Lily said. "I'm ashamed of that."

"Apologies matter. But what you did today mattered more. You gave her back something." The teacher paused. "What changed for you?"

Lily thought about the bathroom. The mirror. The puffy eyes. "Someone said the same kind of thing to me that I'd been saying to her. And I understood, really understood, how it felt."

Ms. Garcia nodded. "That's empathy. It's one of the hardest things to learn—and you learned it the hard way."

Lily and Maya became friends. Real ones.

Sometimes they'd work on the same drawing together—Lily doing the animals and flowers, Maya adding the buildings and machines around them. The pictures they made together were stranger and more interesting than anything either made alone.

"Your art makes mine better," Maya said one afternoon.

"Yours makes mine better too," Lily said.

She thought about the week she'd spent making Maya feel small. About how easy it had been, and how much damage it had done. About how one quiet comment—that's weird—had been enough to push someone to a corner table.

Words moved fast. They spread. They stayed.

She wanted to be more careful with them.

title: The Truth About Winning
description: A story about the truth about winning.
content:
Marcus had spent three weeks on his science fair project. A volcano, sure—but his was good. Detailed diagrams. A real explanation of acid-base reactions. A demonstration that actually worked every single time.

His best friend Tyler was building a solar panel that could power a light bulb. A real working circuit.

"May the best project win," Tyler said as they worked in Tyler's garage.

"Definitely," Marcus agreed, fist-bumping him.

He meant it. Mostly. But somewhere underneath that, he wanted to win more than he'd told anyone, including Tyler. His older brother had taken first place at this fair three years ago. Marcus had the newspaper clipping saved.

The day before the fair, Tyler came to school with red eyes.

"My little brother knocked over the whole display last night. The solar panel shattered. The circuit board is ruined."

Marcus felt his stomach drop for Tyler. He'd watched him build that thing, wire by careful wire.

But something else moved through him too, quieter and less comfortable. A small, private thought: without Tyler's project, my chances just got better.

He hated that he'd thought it. But he had.

That night he couldn't focus. He sat at his desk and stared at his volcano, perfectly intact, ready to go.

Tyler had worked just as hard as he had. Harder, maybe. And now he might not even be able to enter.

It's not your fault his brother knocked it over. True.

You didn't do anything wrong. Also true.

But winning because of someone else's bad luck—winning by accident—that didn't feel like the same thing as actually winning.

At 2 AM, Marcus made up his mind.

He called Tyler first thing in the morning. "Bring all the broken pieces to my house. Right now."

"Why?"

"Just trust me. We have four hours."

When Tyler arrived with a box of shattered parts, Marcus had already cleared the dining room table.

"We're going to fix it."

Tyler stared at him. "But if I enter, I might beat you."

Marcus took a breath. "Maybe. But winning against someone who couldn't even compete doesn't feel like a real win. I'd rather lose to you fair."

Tyler's eyes filled. He didn't say anything. He just opened the box.

They worked fast. Tyler knew exactly how the circuit was supposed to go. Marcus had a steady hand and spare materials in his dad's garage. His mom made sandwiches they ate while soldering.

With fifteen minutes to spare, Tyler connected the rebuilt panel to the light bulb.

It glowed.

They looked at each other and then both started laughing—the kind of laugh that comes when something was almost a disaster and wasn't.

They grabbed their projects and ran.

At the fair, Marcus demonstrated his volcano. Tyler explained the solar panel, and mentioned to the judges that Marcus had helped him rebuild it after an accident—but that the design and science were all his.

The results: third place, Marcus. Second place, Tyler. First place, a girl named Sarah who'd built a working water filtration system.

Marcus felt the disappointment land. Third. He'd wanted first. He'd wanted it for months.

Then Tyler ran over and grabbed him in a hug that nearly knocked him sideways.

The disappointment didn't last long after that. It was hard to hold onto it while Tyler was grinning like that.

That evening Marcus's mom sat with him. "Third place."

"Yeah."

"I'm not proud of the third place."

Marcus looked up.

"I'm proud of the phone call you made this morning. That was harder than any science project."

Later his older brother came to his room. "I heard what happened. You know my first-place trophy from this fair?"

"Yeah. It's in your room."

"It's in a box in the attic. I forgot about it six months later." He sat on the edge of the bed. "But I still think about the time I spent three weeks tutoring Jake in math when he was failing. When he passed his test—that's still there. That didn't go away."

Marcus understood.

The next week, Tyler came over. "Regional fair is next month. Want to do a joint project? Combine chemistry and electrical engineering?"

Marcus's whole face changed. "Yes. Actually yes."

They started brainstorming—chemical reactions that generate electricity, maybe. Something neither of them could have thought of alone.

Marcus had gone into the fair wanting a trophy. He'd come out with something he couldn't put on a shelf. He wasn't sure yet what to call it. But he knew it was worth more.

title: The Courage to Be Different
description: A story about the courage to be different.
content:
Yasmin had been teaching herself to breakdance for two years.

She could do windmills and freezes. She could headstand and backspin. She practiced in her garage after school with the door closed, music loud enough to feel in her feet.

Nobody at school knew. Not even her best friends.

At school, the girls in her grade did ballet or jazz. Pink leotards, pretty music, recitals where everyone brought flowers. Yasmin went to their performances and clapped and said nothing about what she practiced alone in her garage.

When Ms. Rodriguez announced the talent show, Yasmin's heart jumped before she could stop it.

Then Jessica grabbed her arm. "We should do a ballet routine! All of us!" The whole friend group erupted—costumes, matching colors, choreography.

Everyone looked at Yasmin.

She thought about the garage. About the windmill she'd finally landed clean last week.

"Um. Okay," she heard herself say.

Ballet felt wrong in her body. Too still. Too controlled. She kept missing the same turn, the same transition, over and over.

"You're not even trying," Jessica said.

"I am."

"Then try harder. We need to be perfect."

That night Yasmin put on her music and practiced her actual routine. The one she'd built herself, move by move, over two years. Her body knew what to do. She felt awake in a way she didn't feel anywhere else.

Then she remembered the talent show and felt the weight of what she'd agreed to come back down.

Her older brother Karim found her on the porch looking miserable.

She explained. He listened without interrupting.

"So do breakdancing," he said, when she finished.

"Everyone will think it's weird. Girls don't usually—"

"Says who?" He looked at her directly. "You've been doing this for two years. You're good. Like, actually good. Why are you hiding something that makes you happy?"

Yasmin didn't have a clean answer for that.

"Who cares what people think?" he said. "Seriously. Who?"

She thought about it for a long time after he went inside.

The next morning she went to Ms. Rodriguez before school.

Her hands were sweating. "Can I change my entry? To breakdancing?"

Ms. Rodriguez's face lit up. "We've never had a breakdancer. I'd love to see it."

At lunch, Yasmin told her friends.

The table went quiet.

"Breakdancing?" someone said.

"Girls don't really do that," said another.

Jessica looked hurt. "We've been practicing the whole routine."

"I know. I'm sorry." Yasmin kept her voice steady. "But I was only doing ballet because I thought I should. Not because it's actually me."

"This is going to ruin the group," Jessica said.

Yasmin felt her eyes sting. She'd expected this. She'd been afraid of exactly this.

"I hope we're still friends," she said. "But I have to be honest about what I want."

She walked away, legs unsteady.

That afternoon she practiced alone in the garage. Lonely, yes. But she was doing the thing she loved. She hadn't known those two things could exist at the same time until today.

Talent show night.

Jessica and the other girls were backstage in matching costumes. They didn't look at Yasmin. She was in jeans and sneakers and her old hoodie.

She watched the ballet routine from the wings. They were graceful, synchronized, lovely. The crowd applauded warmly.

Then it was her turn.

She walked out and for one second the gym felt enormous and she felt very small.

The music started.

Once the beat hit, her body took over. She didn't have to think. She popped, locked, dropped low. She did a freeze that made the front row go quiet.

Then the windmill—the one she'd landed clean last week. She felt it go right before she was even halfway through.

She finished in her final pose, one hand on the floor, breathing hard.

A second of silence.

Then the gym came apart. People on their feet. Teachers clapping. Kids screaming from the back rows.

Yasmin stood up slowly, not quite believing it.

After the show, kids she'd never talked to were asking her questions. How long have you been doing that? Can you teach me the freeze? What's it called when you spin on your back?

Then Jessica was there.

Yasmin braced herself.

"I'm sorry," Jessica said. "I wasn't being a good friend. You were just being yourself and I made it into a problem." She paused. "You were incredible."

Yasmin felt something unclench in her chest. "Thank you for saying that."

The next week, three girls asked her to teach them. A few boys too. She started a club that met on Thursdays in the gym.

Kids who'd never fit anywhere found a place there.

She hadn't expected that part. She'd just been trying to do the thing she loved, honestly, in front of people.

Turns out that was enough. More than enough.
